page.title: 09The Minack Theatre,St. Levan
page.content: "Minack" comes from Cornish words meaning a stony place. In 1929 a group of Cornish actors staged Shakespeare's "A Midsummer Night's Dream" in a curving slope of meadow above a stream lined with elm, sycamore and willow . "Next year", they said, "we'll do "The Tempest" in the cliff garden of Miss Rowena Cade's house". Three people took six months to make the 1932 grass stage and rough tiered seats built up of dry walling and turf on the slope. People were so gripped by the beauty of the cliff at night, with the added enjoyment of great poetry and live music, that the theatre was kept going. Modern stage and seats (with play names and years engraved) were added by Miss Cade as needed. New dressing rooms modern lighting and sound equipment help actors, a tea bar & cushion hire help audience comfort.
